sections.title: The challenge of embedded authorization
sections.content:
For too long, authorization logic has been tightly woven into application code, leading to monolithic systems that are hard to change, secure, and scale. Every new feature, every policy adjustment, every application integration becomes a complex, risky, and time-consuming development task.

Off-the-shelf access management solutions often offer too much or too little, failing to meet the unique, fine-grained access control requirements of modern, distributed applications. They can be expensive, difficult to integrate fully, and leave you dependent on vendor roadmaps.

It's time to take control of your access policies and build dedicated, flexible authorization services that serve all your applications.

sections.title: Why build a custom externalized authorization service?
sections.content:
## Decouple and empower your applications

Externalized authorization means moving the decision-making process for 'who can do what' out of your application's code and into a dedicated, centralized service. This architectural shift offers profound benefits:

### Enhanced Security Posture
With a single source of truth for authorization policies, you reduce the risk of inconsistencies and vulnerabilities across your applications. Policies are enforced consistently, and audits become simpler and more reliable.

### Unmatched Flexibility and Agility
Need to change an access rule? No need to redeploy your entire application. Update the policy in your central service, and changes are instantly reflected across all integrated systems. This accelerates feature delivery and policy adjustments.

### Simplified Developer Experience
Developers can focus on core business logic rather than complex authorization rules. Applications make a simple request to your authorization service, receiving an immediate 'allow' or 'deny' decision.

### Granular Control and Context-Aware Decisions
Go beyond simple role-based access. Implement attribute-based access control (ABAC) or even relationship-based access control (RBAC). Your custom service can leverage real-time context (e.g., time of day, device, location, data sensitivity) to make highly nuanced authorization decisions.

### Scalability by Design
Your authorization service can scale independently of your applications, handling high request volumes without impacting application performance. As your user base grows or your microservices expand, your authorization layer can keep pace.

### Ownership and Cost Efficiency
Avoid recurring subscription fees and vendor lock-in. A custom solution built with Kliv is a capital investment that gives you full ownership and control over your critical security infrastructure.

## Real-world applications of Externalized Authorization

Custom externalized authorization is critical for complex environments:

**Multi-tenant SaaS Platforms**: Dynamically restrict what each tenant's users can see or do, even if sharing the same underlying data structure.

**Financial Services**: Implement highly detailed transaction approval flows, ensuring compliance with regulatory requirements and internal risk policies based on transaction amount, user role, and fraud scores.

**Healthcare Systems**: Enforce HIPAA compliance by allowing access to patient records only for authorized personnel based on their role and the patient's consent status.

**IoT and Edge Devices**: Authorize device-to-device communication and command execution based on device identity, location, and operational state.

**Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP)**: Control access to specific modules, data rows, or even individual fields within ERP records based on departmental roles and approval hierarchies.

## Building your solution with AI

Kliv's platform leverages AI to dramatically simplify the creation of sophisticated authorization services. You describe your policy requirements, integration points, and desired features using natural language, and the AI assists in generating a robust, secure, and scalable solution. This means:

- **Faster Development**: Launch your authorization service in days, not months.
- **Reduced Errors**: AI helps ensure policies are correctly translated and enforced.
- **Iterative Improvement**: Easily refine and extend your policies as business needs evolve.

sections.title: Externalized authorization ideas to get you started

items.description: Control access to documents based on user roles and document classification.
items.prompt: Create an externalized authorization service for a document management system. It should apply role-based access control (RBAC) where 'admin' can view/edit all, 'editor' can view/edit specific categories, and 'viewer' can only view. Also, implement attribute-based access control (ABAC) that restricts access to 'confidential' documents unless the user has 'senior_approver' attribute and is in the 'legal' department.
items.title: Document access control

items.description: Manage user permissions for features within a multi-tenant SaaS application.
items.prompt: Build a multi-tenant authorization service for a SaaS platform. Each tenant has isolated policies. Users within a tenant have roles like 'owner', 'manager', 'employee'. 'Owner' can access all tenant features and settings. 'Manager' can manage users and projects but not billing. 'Employee' can only access assigned projects. The service should also allow dynamic feature toggles per tenant.
items.title: Multi-tenant SaaS feature access

items.description: Authorize API calls based on issuer identity and request context.
items.prompt: Develop an authorization microservice for an API gateway. It should validate JWT tokens for user identity, then evaluate access to specific API endpoints based on granular permissions associated with the user's roles and the HTTP method. Add conditions to deny access if the request originates from a blacklisted IP address or outside of business hours.
items.title: API Gateway Authorization

items.description: Control which devices can perform certain actions in an IoT network.
items.prompt: Design an authorization service for an IoT platform. Devices should have unique IDs. Policies should dictate which device types can interact with specific actuators. For example, 'temperature_sensor_A' can only read from 'HVAC_unit_1' but 'maintenance_robot_B' can send 'calibrate' commands. Include temporal conditions for maintenance windows.
items.title: IoT Device Access Control

items.description: Implement payment approval workflows with dynamic conditions.
items.prompt: Create an authorization service for a payment processing system. Payments require approval. Amounts over $1000 require two manager approvals. Payments over $10000 require CFO approval. Users cannot approve their own payments. Fraud scores from an external service must also be below a certain threshold for approval to be granted.
items.title: Financial Transaction Approval

sections.title: Ways to enhance your authorization service

items.prompt: Add a policy administration UI that allows non-technical users to create and manage access policies using a visual editor.
items.title: Policy administration UI

items.prompt: Implement a real-time policy update mechanism, so changes to policies are instantly propagated to all consuming applications without downtime.
items.title: Real-time policy updates

items.prompt: Integrate with a secrets management service (e.g., AWS Secrets Manager, HashiCorp Vault) to securely store and retrieve policy configurations or API keys.
items.title: Secrets management integration

items.prompt: Add auditing and logging capabilities, recording every authorization decision (allow/deny) with contextual information for compliance and debugging.
items.title: Comprehensive auditing and logging

items.prompt: Develop a caching layer for popular policy decisions to reduce latency and improve performance for frequent authorization requests.
items.title: Policy decision caching

items.prompt: Build in multi-factor authentication (MFA) requirements for specific high-privilege actions, leveraging an external MFA provider.
items.title: Contextual MFA enforcement

items.prompt: Add support for Open Policy Agent (OPA) integration, allowing policies to be written in Rego and evaluated by your service.
items.title: OPA (Rego) policy support

items.answer: Kliv's platform accelerates development significantly. A basic externalized authorization service with common policies can be operational in a few days. More complex systems with advanced policy engines and UI will take longer but still far less time than traditional development.
items.question: How long does it take to build an externalized authorization service?

items.answer: While some technical understanding of authorization concepts is beneficial, Kliv's AI reduces or eliminates the need for direct coding. You define requirements and policies using natural language, and the platform assists in generating the underlying code and infrastructure.
items.question: Do I need deep coding expertise to build this?

items.answer: Yes, a custom externalized authorization service is designed for maximum integration. It can connect with identity providers (like Okta, Auth0, active directory) for user information and with virtually any application or microservice via APIs (REST, gRPC, etc.).
items.question: Can it integrate with my existing identity provider and applications?

items.answer: You retain full ownership of the generated code and the authorization logic. Unlike SaaS solutions, you can choose where to deploy it, how to scale it, and how to maintain it, giving you complete control and mitigating vendor lock-in.
items.question: Who owns the authorization logic and generated code?

items.answer: A custom solution typically involves a higher upfront investment compared to monthly SaaS subscriptions. However, over 1-2 years, it often proves more cost-effective due to no recurring fees, ability to customize without add-on costs, and direct control over infrastructure.
items.question: How does the cost compare to off-the-shelf authorization solutions?

items.answer: Yes, full flexibility is a key advantage. You can iteratively refine policies, add new attributes, support new access models, or integrate with more applications as your business evolves, all without being limited by a vendor's feature set.
items.question: Can I modify or extend the authorization service after it‚Äôs built?

items.answer: Building your own allows for a 'security by design' approach. You control the deployment environment, data residency, and underlying security configurations. You can implement specific compliance requirements that off-the-shelf solutions might not meet, potentially making it more secure for your specific needs.
